conclusion: Determine the magnitude of the normal force \( F_N \) between the latch \( D \) and the lock groove \( E \) when the system is in a self-locking state.
From Figure B, the forces acting on the latch \( D \) are spring force \( F_{\text{spring}} = kx \), normal force \( F_N \), and friction force \( f = \mu F_N \).
Spring force acts horizontally to the right, normal force acts perpendicular to the inclined surface, and friction force opposes the motion of the latch.
Resolve forces into components along and perpendicular to the inclined plane.
Inclination angle of the latch is \( \theta = 30^\circ \).
Spring force components: \( F_{\text{spring, parallel}} = kx \cos\theta \) and \( F_{\text{spring, perpendicular}} = kx \sin\theta \).
Normal force components: \( F_{N, parallel} = F_N \sin\theta \) and \( F_{N, perpendicular} = F_N \cos\theta \).
Friction force acts along the inclined plane, opposing the motion.
For self-locking, the latch must be in equilibrium with net force along both horizontal and vertical directions being zero.
Force balance along the inclined plane: \( kx \cos\theta = \mu F_N + F_N \sin\theta \).
Force balance perpendicular to the inclined plane: \( F_N \cos\theta = kx \sin\theta \).
This equation is consistent with the geometry but does not provide additional information for solving \( F_N \).
Substitute into the expression for \( F_N \): \( F_N = \frac{kx \cdot \frac{\sqrt{3}}{2}}{\mu + \frac{1}{2}} \).
Simplify to get the final answer: \( F_N = \frac{\sqrt{3} kx}{2 (\mu + \frac{1}{2})} \).
